title: Why are Russians so stingy with their smiles?
excerpt: In the US, smiling is a reflexive gesture of goodwill, but Russians view it as a sign of stupidity. Social psychology research could help explain this cultural contrast.

title: An Illustrated Guide to Mouth Gestures and Their Meanings Around the World
excerpt: An excerpt from François Caradec’s book “Dictionary of Gestures.”

title: How the Brain Links Gestures, Perception and Meaning
excerpt: Neuroscience has found that gestures are not merely important as tools of expression but as guides of cognition and perception.

title: When Did Shaking Hands Become a Standard Way of Greeting Someone?
excerpt: There’s ancient evidence for the custom of shaking hands, but did it mean the same thing then as it does today?

title: The Way Humans Point Isn’t as Universal as You Might Think
excerpt: It was long thought that humans everywhere favor pointing with the index finger. But some fieldwork out of Papua New Guinea identified a group of people who prefer to scrunch their noses.

title: Why Do We Gesture When We Talk?
excerpt: Gesture researchers have spent the past 40 years uncovering how movements (like a cupped hand rotating in space or a finger tracing a path through the air) are intimately tied to speech.

title: The evolutionary psychology of talking with your hands - Big Think
excerpt: A team of researchers from the Netherlands found that hands gestures, when used strategically, influence how certain words are heard.
